    Processing global data in R An Example ELSA Workflow

    Load different types of data

    elsar_load_data.Rd

    Load different types of data

    Usage

    elsar_load_data(
  file_name,
  file_path = NULL,
  file_lyr = NULL,
  file_type,
  wkt_filter = FALSE,
  bb_extend = NULL,
  db_info = NULL,
  pg_connection = NULL,
  iso3_column = "iso3cd",
  iso3
)

    Arguments

    file_name

    character of the file name. Needs to contain the file type ending (e.g. .tif) if loading from a local source.

    file_path

    path where local file is stored. Needs to be NULL when using postgres.

    file_lyr

    optional. Layer information of data.

    file_type

    character of file type. Current options are: "postgres", "shp", "gpkg", "geojson", "tif", "tiff", "grd", "gri", "nc", "hdf"

    wkt_filter

    character; WKT representation of a spatial filter that is used to bound loaded data

    bb_extend

    SpatRaster used as bounding box when wkt_filter = TRUE, e.g. planning units

    db_info

    list in the style of a dictionary. Only needed when file_type = "postgres". Needs to have the following structure and information: postgres_dict <- c(host = "", dbname ="", port = , user = "", password = "")

    pg_connection

    Either a list in the style of a dictionary or a connection string. Only needed when file_type = "postgres".

    iso3_column

    Only relevant when file_type "postgres" is selected. A string of the name of where iso3 information can be found in a dataset.

    iso3

    The iso3 country code (character) of the country of interest.

    Value

    The loaded data either as a SpatRaster or sf object

    Examples

    if (FALSE) {
load_tif <- elsar_load_data(
  file_name = "pu_nepal_450m.tif", file_path = localPath,
  file_type = "tif"
)

load_geojson <- elsar_load_data(
  file_name = "nepal.geojson", file_path = localPath,
  file_type = "geojson"
)

postgres_dict <- c(
  host = "yourhost",
  dbname = "yourdbname",
  port = portNumber,
  user = "yourusername",
  password = "yourpassword"
)

load_postgres <- elsar_load_data(
  file_name = "bnda_simplified",
  file_type = "postgres",
  db_info = postgres_dict,
  iso3_column = "iso3cd",
  iso3 = "NPL"
)

pg_conn <- make_postgres_connection(
  dbname = "yourdatabase",
  user = "yourusername",
  password = "yourpassword"
)

load_postgres <- elsar_load_data(
  file_name = "bnda_simplified",
  file_type = "postgres",
  pg_connection = pg_conn,
  iso3_column = "iso3cd",
  iso3 = "NPL"
)
}
